timeline.bodyText: Do we really need hasNext local variable here? return true seems enough.
timeline.author: petrpleshachkov
petrpleshachkov

timeline.bodyText: If I call hasNext() multiple times it shouldn't advance the iterator, but it seems it does.
timeline.author: petrpleshachkov

timeline.bodyText: Is this method called on the partition thread?
timeline.author: petrpleshachkov

replies.bodyText: yes, when it is not global index or i can't find counter example at least. I have added check assertRunningOnPartitionThread when index is not global.
replies.author: ahmetmircik

timeline.bodyText: Not sure that we need hasNextCallCount and nextCallCount. Why not using just next? If it is not null the hasNext() returns true immediately. The next() will first call hasNext() and if it exists, return it (assigning next to null). Something similar to the HDBplusTree#EntryIterator.
timeline.author: petrpleshachkov

replies.bodyText: but in that case consecutive hasNext calls advance state, i don't want it to happen.
replies.author: ahmetmircik

replies.bodyText: No, it'll check that next variable is not null and return quickly.
replies.author: petrpleshachkov

replies.bodyText: Oops i see now, my test was wrong, also fixed it, thx.
replies.author: ahmetmircik

timeline.bodyText: I'm a bit lost here. Now we don't update the isIndexStoreExpirable field anywhere but we still use the return value from BaseIndexStore#isExpirable in three places. Can you elaborate on this change?
timeline.author: mmedenjak

replies.bodyText: leftover, removed that method and related stuff.
replies.author: ahmetmircik

replies.bodyText: Still, can you elaborate a bit on how it's safe to remove all of that code? With the removal, the dependant code now acts as if isExpirable() == false, always.
replies.author: mmedenjak
ahmetmircik

timeline.message: optimize for non expirable record stores
optimize for non expirable record stores 2
optimize for non expirable record stores 3
optimize for non expirable record stores 4
